analytic.title: Ecosystem restoration through aerial seeding -interacting plant-soil microbiome effects on soil multifunctionality

div.p: Understanding the driving factors of soil multifunctionality is of great significance for the protection and restoration of degraded terrestrial ecosystems. However, the effects of above-and belowground factors are rarely evaluated simultaneously, and the driving mode of both factors on soil multifunctionality is not clear. Here, we evaluated restoration of mobile dunes threatened by desertification through aerial seeding, i.e., the sowing of seeds through aerial devices, from 1983 to 2015 in Mu Us Desert, China, using soil and plant data. The effect of aerial seeding on the restoration of soil multifunctionality, plant diversity, and soil microbial diversity in mobile dunes was significant, which tested by loess regression. Further, the plant diversity becomes saturated in the later stages of restoration. The effect also leads to the restoration of soil multifunctionality lags behind plant and soil microorganisms. The factors (plant and soil microorganisms) driving soil multifunctionality is not a separate action or a joint action which test by structural equation models (SEMs), but that plants restore first and then indirectly drive soil multifunctionality through soil microorganisms during the restoration process. We also found that bacteria are the main direct indicators of soil multifunctionality which tested using Random Forests modelling. This study highlights that plants indirectly drive soil multifunctionality through soil microorganisms, and soil microorganisms are key to elucidating the restoration mechanism and process.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: An ecosystem has great value because it can maintain multiple functions and services simultaneously (Multifunctionality) (Zavaleta, Pasari, Hulvey, & Tilman, 2010). Soil is an important foundation of the ecosystem, and the integrity of soil multifunctionality is the basis for the realization of ecosystem functions and services (Zheng et al., 2019). It has long been recognized that biodiversity can be the mechanism behind the performance of an ecosystem, whether it is the aboveground organisms or the soil microorganisms belowground (Hector & Bagchi, 2007;Hector & Hooper, 2002;Peter et al., 2011). Biodiversity loss is recognized as a global concern as increasing evidence shows its negative effects on ecosystems, reducing the quantity and quality of ecosystem functions and services (Hooper et al., 2005;IPBES, 2019). Therefore, it is important to explore the driving effect of biodiversity on the multifunctionality of soil, especially on degraded land undergoing long-term restoration. Understanding the relationship between plants, soil microorganisms, soil multifunctionality and restoration time, and the driving effect of above-and belowground factors on soil multifunctionality can inform the protection and restoration of ecosystems.

During restoration, the relationship between components (such as plants, soil microorganisms, and soil multifunctionality) and restoration time will vary, as will the response of individual components to restoration time. Most studies in the terrestrial environment have shown that with ecological restoration, plants (Baer, Adams, Scott, Blair, & Collins, 2019;K. Liu et al., 2020), soil microorganisms (Yan et al., 2019;Zhong et al., 2019), and soil multifunctionality (Yan et al., 2019;Zhong et al., 2019) will gradually restore, with a positive linear relationship. However, in some studies of soil microorganisms, it has been found that the response to ecological restoration can become saturated (i.e., the diversity of soil microorganisms does not increase after a certain number of years) (Klopf, Baer, Bach, & Six, 2017) and lagging can occur (i.e., soil microorganisms do not respond immediately to restoration, but have a time interval before recovery begins) (Boeddinghaus et al., 2019;Strickland et al., 2017). Analyzing the relationship between components in ecosystem restoration, restoration time, and their response will more clearly describe the ecological restoration process.

The driving effect of plant diversity on ecosystem multifunctionality was the first to receive attention. Since then, a large number of studies have proved that ecosystem functions and plant diversity are positively correlated (Lefcheck et al., 2015;Tilman, Lehman, & Thomson, 1997).

Some studies have shown that the increase of species richness can promote net primary productivity (Maestre et al., 2012;Naeem, Thompson, Lawler, Lawton, & Woodfin, 1994) and resource utilization efficiency, such as more diverse producers per unit area having a higher photosynthetic rate (Cardinale et al., 2011;Tilman & Downing, 1994). At the same time, it can produce more decomposition and lower debris inventory (Srivastava et al., 2009), thereby promoting the circulation of elements and the storage of organic matter. After the emergence of high-throughput sequencing technology, the impact of soil microorganisms on ecosystem multifunctionality attracted increased attention (Srivastava et al., 2009). Most studies found a positive correlation between soil multifunctionality and soil microbial diversity (Delgado-Baquerizo et al., 2016;Wagg, Bender, Widmer, & van der Heijden, 2014), but some studies show the opposite (Wang et al., 2020). At the same time, an increasing number of studies have confirmed the driving role of soil microbial diversity on ecosystem multifunctionality (Barber, Chantos-Davidson, Amel Peralta, Sherwood, & Swingley, 2017;Delgado-Baquerizo et al., 2016;Wagg et al., 2014). Microorganisms support ecosystem multifunctionality in numerous ways and play a key role in maintaining the operation of ecosystems (Jiao et al., 2018). First, soil microbial diversity contributing to the biogeochemical cycling of soil nutrients (Falkowski et al., 2008;Tedersoo et al., 2014). Second, soil microbial diversity acting as decomposers, mutualists, or pathogens to influence the growth of macroorganisms (Dantas & Sommer, 2014). Third, soil microbial diversity can also emitting greenhouse gases that may accelerate global climate change (Davidson & Janssens, 2006). A recent study has found that the combined effects of plant diversity and soil microbial diversity on soil multifunctionality are more explanatory than either of the two alone (Jing et al., 2015). Based on the combined effects, Delgado-Baquerizo et al. (2016) have further explored the driving mode of plant and soil microbial diversity on soil multifunctionality and found that plant diversity has a significant indirect effect on soil multifunctionality through soil microbial diversity.

Although many studies have confirmed the driving effect of above-and belowground factors on soil multifunctionality, two main issues remain unresolved. First, previous studies have been conducted under natural recovery, the effects of above-and belowground factors are rarely evaluated simultaneously in artificially restored degraded ecosystem, and the driving mode of the two on soil multifunctionality is not clear. For example, it is still unclear whether above-or belowground factors are the dominant driver of ecosystem multifunctionality (Maestre et al., 2012;Wagg et al., 2014); or if it is co-driven (Jing et al., 2015;Lefcheck et al., 2015); or if it is a more complex driving model, such as the coexistence of direct and indirect effects. Second, only a few studies have been carried out based on long-term artificial restoration. However, the restoration gradient can better reflect the difference in the overall environment (Bach, Baer, Meyer, & Six, 2010). Evaluating the above-and belowground factors of soil multifunctionality on the restoration gradient can characterize the driving mode more clearly. Therefore, evaluating soil multifunctionality and its above-and belowground driving factors under an artificial restoration gradient can deepen our understanding of restoration mechanisms and provide guidance for artificially restoring degraded land.

The ecological transition zone of the Mu Us Desert from the Ordos Plateau to the Loess Plateau in China is characterized as an ecotone of pasture, forest, and agriculture and is considered an ecologically fragile zone. Accordingly, this area has been the focus of national policies for ecological restoration, with the land exhibiting varying degrees of land degradation and being threatened by desertification over many years (Q. Liu et al., 2020). To restore the ecological environment, a number of major ecological restoration policies have been implemented since 1978 in northern China (Q. Zhang et al., 2020), including the Three Norths Shelter Forest Program (TNSFP), Combating of Desertification Program (CDP), Natural Forest Protection Project (NFPP), and Grain for Green Project (GGP) (Jia et al., 2014;Li et al., 2012;Wu et al., 2013), and different ecological restoration policies has specific implementation measures. For mobile dunes -a degraded ecosystem in the Mu Us Desert -that can be slow or unable to recover naturally without manual intervention (L. Zhang et al., 2018), a regularly used plantation technique to promote artificial recovery is aerial seeding. This technique involves sowing seeds by broadcasting on the ground through aerial devices, including drones, planes, or helicopters. In this study, we analyzed the restoration of plant diversity, soil microbial diversity, and soil multifunctionality based on a 30-year aerial seeding restoration gradient in the Mu Us Desert, examining the driving modes of above-and belowground factors on soil multifunctionality. Our aims were to (1) investigate how plant and soil microbial diversity and soil multifunctionality respond to time during the aerial seeding restoration process. (2) Exploring the relationship between above-belowground factors and soil multifunctionality and see how those factors drive soil multifunctionality.

div.head: Study area
div.p: The Mu Us Desert (106¬∞11‚Ä≤ -110¬∞54‚Ä≤ E, 36¬∞49‚Ä≤ -40¬∞12‚Ä≤ N) encompasses Shaanxi Province, the Ningxia Hui, and Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region. Aerial seeding is implemented by local forestry departments, with varying methods used in different provinces. In order to avoid the impact of different implementation methods, we selected sample sites within the Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region that used the same aerial seeding techniques and are located in the core of the Mu Us Desert (Fig. 1). The area has a temperate arid to semi-arid continental monsoon climate, and mean annual temperature of 6.2 ‚ÑÉ, a mean annual precipitation of approximately 250 mm, and an elevation of approximately 1300 m. The Mu Us Desert has variable topography with various landforms, including active dunes, semi-fixed dunes, and fixed dunes. The main soil types are Kastanozems, Arenosols, Histosols, and Solonchaks. The zonal vegetation is dominated by Stipa bungeana and Thymus serpyllum plant communities, while sandy vegetation is dominated by Artemisia ordosica, Salix psammophyla, and Sabina vulgaris.

The specific implementation measures of these ecological restoration projects mainly include the following (Gao, Wang, Wang, Van, & Li, 2005): aerial seeding of trees and grass; afforestation; blockades for sand movement; setting wind barriers in sand dunes; building fences around grasslands; prohibiting grazing; cultivating high-quality grass species; building livestock sheds; providing feed and machinery for herders; prohibiting timber harvests; strengthening forest divisions; providing subsidies for food, living expenses, and afforestation fees to farmers who return farmland for afforestation; ecological immigration; return of forestry (grass) ownership to farmers, etc. The situation of degraded land is different, and it corresponds to different implementation measures, as there is almost no vegetation cover on the mobile dunes in the Mu Us Desert, other measures cannot help its restoration, so that the most suitable measure is aerial seeding (L. Zhang et al., 2018). The aerial seeding in the study area uses planes to broadcast the tree (grass) seed suitable for the local environment on the barren hills or sandy land and carry out enclosure and care management, until the vegetation is restored, and the purpose of sand prevention and control is achieved. Aerial seeding has been implemented since the 1980s and has continued to this day. The main species being broadcast are Hedysarum laeve Maxim and Hedysarum scoparium. We selected 30 sites that have been aerial seeded from 1983 to 2015 (excluding 1986, 1988, and 2003), one nonaerial seeding mobile dune site, and one original (top community and undisturbed > 30 years) reference site, for a total of 32 sample sites (the information about each field sites see TABLE 1). We determine the aerial seeding time of the sites based on the records of the local forestry bureau.

Since the 1980s, there have been many local plots for aerial seeding every year, but it can't ensure the success of all plots. We choose the successful restoration area as study sites. The initial state of the degraded sites before aerial seeding was mobile dunes.

div.head: Site setting and sample collection
div.p: Plant and soil samples were collected in August 2017. To ensure the 32 field sites had the same resource acquisition capacity, we established sites on flat land placed between dunes to make their topography consistent. First, we choose a relatively homogeneous site of 10 √ó 10-m in each aerial seeding area, and then sampled three 1 √ó 1-m plots along the diagonal at each site and recorded the number of species and number of plants per species. We then cut off the aboveground part of the plant before we dried it in an oven at 65 ‚ÑÉ to a constant weight. We also used a soil auger at each plot to drill two samples of 0-60 cm soil, one of which was stored at room temperature to determine soil nutrient content; the other sample was stored at -20 ¬∞C and used for the extraction of soil microorganisms (fungi and bacteria) DNA. A root auger was used to drill one sample of 0-60 cm soil for each plot, and we cleaned the roots of the plants and placed them in an oven at 65 ‚ÑÉ to dry to a constant weight. We obtained mean annual temperature and annual precipitation data for the field sites from the WorldClim v2.1 database (http://www.worldclim.org/; 30 arc-sec, 1970-2000).

Although the aerial seeding was from 1983 to 2015, we considered that the broad patterns represented by these long-term datasets could still accurately represent environmental conditions for the field sites.

To investigate processes related to desertification, we investigated six soil ecosystem functions that provide basic support and regulation services (Isbell et al., 2011) and are closely related to the desertification process (Maestre & Escudero, 2009). The soil ecosystem functions were: total organic carbon (TOC), total nitrogen (TN), total phosphorus (TP), ammonium nitrogen (NH4 + ), nitrate nitrogen (NO3 -), and available phosphorus (AP). We measured TOC using the potassium dichromate (K2Cr2O7) heating oxidation method, TN using the selenium-cupric sulfate (CuSO4)potassium sulfate (K2SO4)-heating digestion method, TP using the alkali fusion-Mo-Sb colorimetric method, NH4 + , and NO3 -using the Kjeldahl nitrogen determination method, and AP using the sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3) leaching-Mo-Sb colorimetric method.

div.head: Soil microbial sequencing
div.p: Fungi and bacteria DNA were extracted using the E.Z.N.A. ¬Æ Soil DNA Kit (D4015, Omega, Inc., USA) according to the manufacturer's instructions. The ITS2 region of the fungi small-subunit rRNA gene was amplified with slightly modified versions of primers fITS7 (5'-GTGARTCATCGAATCTTTG-3') and ITS4 (5'-TCCTCCGCTTATTGATATGC-3'). The V3-V4 region of the bacterial small-subunit (16S) rRNA gene was amplified with slightly modified versions of primers 338F (5'-ACTCCTACGGGAGGCAGCAG-3') and 806R

(5'-GGACTACHVGGGTWTCTAAT-3') (Fadrosh et al., 2014). These amplified polymerase chain reaction products were sequenced on the Illumina HiSeq 2500 platform (Illumina Inc., San Diego, CA) using 250-bp paired-end reads. Quality filtering on the raw tags was performed under specific filtering conditions to obtain the high-quality clean tags according to the FastQC (V 0.10.1).
Chimeric sequences were filtered using Verseach software (v2.3.4). Sequences with ‚â• 97% similarity were assigned to the same operational taxonomic units (OTUs) by Verseach (v2.3.4).

Representative sequences were chosen for each OUT (Blaxter et al., 2005), and taxonomic data were then assigned to each representative sequence using the RDP (Ribosomal Database Project) classifier (Caporaso et al., 2011).
2.2.4. Calculation of plant and soil microbial diversity and soil multifunctionality

For plant diversity, we defined species richness as the total number of species from the three plots within each site. We then calculated the Shannon-Wiener index (H‚Ä≤) for each site based on plant species abundance information:
S represents the total number of species, and pi represents the proportion of the i-th species to the total.
For soil microbial diversity, we used OTU richness to represent species richness. We then calculated the Shannon-Wiener index (H‚Ä≤) based on soil microbial species abundance information.

We next performed principal coordinates analysis (PCoA) based on the Bray-Curtis distance matrix between samples, with the two axes of PCoA (PCoA1 and PCoA2) representing species differences between sites.

To estimate the soil multifunctionality, we took the average across all soil ecosystem functions for the three plots in each site. We used the threshold method to calculate the soil multifunctionality index, a new framework recently proposed for calculating multifunctionality while avoiding bias caused by overweighting some categories of ecosystem function (Manning et al., 2018). In this framework, a cluster analysis was conducted to identify the closely related functions assigned to the same cluster. Each cluster was then assigned equal weight, and functions within the cluster are weighted equally. The multifunctionality index was next calculated according to the threshold methods to count the weight of functions exceeding above a certain threshold in each site. In this study, four clusters were found to be appropriate for the six ecosystem functions using the "factoextra" package in R v3.5.1 (Fig. S1). For each ecosystem function, we defined the 25%, 50%, and 75% of the highest ten values (5% of data) as the threshold, respectively, and calculated the average weight of functions exceeding thresholds per site.

div.head: Data analysis
div.p: 2.3.1. The response of plant, soil microbial diversity and soil multifunctionality to the restoration time, and the relationship between plant, soil microbial diversity and soil multifunctionality A series of loess regression were run to inspect linear and non-linear relationships of plant, soil microbial diversity and soil multifunctionality to the restoration time of aerial seeding, finally, we selected the models with the highest R 2 as the optimal model. We performed separate Pearson's correlation coefficient analyses to determine the strength of the relationship between plants, soil microorganisms and soil multifunctionality.

div.head: The driving mode of above-and belowground factors to soil multifunctionality
div.p: To further determine the driving mode of plant and microbial diversity on soil multifunctionality, we used structural equation models (SEMs) using the "lavaan" package in R v3.5.1. Before constructing the SEMs, we examined the impact of climatic factors on soil multifunctionality, finding a significant correlation between annual precipitation and soil multifunctionality, but not between mean annual temperature and soil multifunctionality (Fig. S2). Therefore, we only included PCoA1, Bacteria PCoA2, Fungus species richness, Fungus shannon, Fungus PCoA1, and Fungus PCoA2.

div.head: Analysis of direct driving factors of soil multifunctionality
div.p: We further analyzed all variables above-and belowground were used as predictors, and Random Forests (RF) modelling was used to analyze the driving factors of soil multifunctionality based on the "randomForest" package in R v3.5.1. The percentage increase of the mean squared error (%IncMSE) of a variable was used to evaluate the importance of each variable. The higher the %IncMSE value, the more important the variable. The significance of each predictor on the response variables was assessed with the "rfPermute" package in R v3.5.1, and significance of the models and cross-validated R 2 values were assessed with 5000 permutations of the response variable using the "A3" package in R v3.5.1. Finally, Canonical Correspondence Analysis (CCA) was used to test the relationship between specific bacterial genera and individual soil functions using the "vegan" package in R v3.5.1.
All data analyses were conducted using R v3.5.1 (http:// www.r-project.org/) unless otherwise stated.

div.head: The response of plant and soil microbial diversity and soil multifunctionality to the restoration time
div.p: On the whole, plant and soil microbial diversity and soil multifunctionality increased significantly with restoration time. Among the responses, plant species richness and Shannon diversity have a downward quadratic function relationship with restoration time, showing a saturation trend (Fig. 2A,B). Species richness and Shannon diversity of fungi and bacteria have positive linear relationships with restoration time (Fig. 2C,D,E,F). The relationship between soil multifunctionality and restoration time is an upward quadratic function, with no increasing trend in the early stage of restoration, consistent with a hysteresis phenomenon (Fig. 2G).

div.head: The relationship between plant and soil microbial diversity and soil multifunctionality
div.p: Overall, most plant and soil microbial variables are significantly positively correlated with soil multifunctionality. Among the responses, plant diversity and underground biomass are significantly positively correlated with soil multifunctionality (Fig. 3A,B,D), whereas the relationship between above-ground biomass of plants and soil multifunctionality was positive but not significant (Fig. 3C). Fungal species richness and PCoA1 are significantly positively correlated with soil multifunctionality (Fig. 3E,G). Fungal Shannon index and PCoA2 are not significantly correlated with soil multifunctionality (Fig. 3F,H). Bacterial species diversity and PCoA1 have a significant positive correlation with soil multifunctionality (Fig. 3I, J, K), and bacterial PCoA2 has no significant relationship with soil multifunctionality (Fig. 3L).

div.head: The driving mode of above-and belowground factors to soil multifunctionality
div.p: Each SEM model has high goodness of fit (the value of CFI > 0.90, the p value of œá 2 > 0.05 are considered as good goodness of fit). In the four SEMs, annual precipitation had a significant effect on soil multifunctionality, but the effect is weak and had no significant effect on other variables (Fig. 4). In the first model, the SEM was constructed according to the assumption that plants drive soil multifunctionality, and it was found that the driving path of the plant to the soil multifunctionality was not significant (Fig. 4A). In the second model, the SEM was constructed with the assumption that soil microorganisms drive soil multifunctionality, and it was found that the driving path was also not significant (Fig. 4B). In the third model, no expected synergy was found in the SEM that examines the soil multifunctionality driven by plants and soil microorganisms, with the path of plants on soil multifunctionality being non-significant (Fig. 4C). In order to test that plants indirectly drive soil multifunctionality through microorganisms, the path from plants to soil microorganisms was connected in the fourth SEM, and it was found that this path was significant. At the same time, a significant tandem pathway was formed by restoration time-plant-soil microorganism-soil multifunctionality. This result is consistent with the expected fourth driving mode (SEM) (Fig. 4D).

div.head: The direct driving factors of soil multifunctionality
div.p: Random forest analysis results show that 4 of the 12 predictors of soil multifunctionality have significant effects and are all soil bacteria-related factors (Fig. 5). The CCA analysis shows that TN and SOC are positively correlated with the relative abundances of Gp10 and Ilumatobacter bacteria, respectively. The NO3 -is positively correlated with the relative abundance of Nitrospira, Gp17, and Bacillus. The TP, AP, and NH4 + are not strongly related to bacteria of each genus (Fig. 6).

div.head: The restoration of plant diversity appears saturated during the restoration process of aerial seeding in mobile dunes, and the restoration of soil multifunctionality has a lagging effect
div.p: In this study in the Mu Us Desert, we found that plant diversity, soil microbial diversity, and soil multifunctionality increased with time since aerial seeding began in the 1980s (Fig. 2). This indicates that aerial seeding has played a positive role in the restoration of plants, microorganisms, and soil in the mobile dunes, with substantial restoration of degraded areas, consistent with the findings of L. Zhang et al. (2018).

Although plant, soil microbial diversity, and soil multifunctionality all increased with increasing time since aerial seeding, the restoration led to saturation of plant diversity at an earlier stage (Fig. 2A,B). Further, compared to plants, and soil microbial diversity, there is a hysteresis effect in soil multifunctionality recovery, which did not increase significantly in the early stage of aerial seeding (Fig. 2G). This suggests that plant and soil microbial diversity and soil multifunctionality respond differently to restoration from aerial seeding (Boeddinghaus et al., 2019;Strickland et al., 2017). Our results show that plants and soil microorganisms respond quickly to restoration via aerial seeding, but that the response of soil multifunctionality lagged substantially after, and show an exponential response trend. This may be because soil recovery is driven by plants and microorganisms, so the response of soil multifunctionality follows later (Harris, 2009), and the exponential response trend indicates that the soil multifunctionality might be driven by the interactive effects of above-ground plant and below-ground soil microbial communities. In addition, this lag response of soil multifunctionality also indicates that above-ground restoration did not mean a same restoration in below ground.

div.head: Plants have a significant indirect effect on the restoration of soil multifunctionality through soil microorganisms
div.p: In early research, studies mainly focused on the driving effect of plants on the multifunctionality of the ecosystem (Tilman et al., 1997). With the development of soil microbial research, the driving role of underground microbes on the multifunctionality of ecosystems have gradually gained attention. Consequently, studies have increasingly confirmed that the multifunctionality of terrestrial ecosystems is driven by the diversity of plants and soil microorganisms (Jing et al., 2015;Lefcheck et al., 2015). The present study found that the relationship between plant and soil microbial indicators and soil multifunctionality were mainly positively correlated (Fig. 3). However, the first three SEM models are all not valid (Fig. 4A,B,C). Nevertheless, it is feasible that plants indirectly drive soil multifunctionality through microorganisms (Fig. 4D), with this finding being consistent with Delgado-Baquerizo et al. ( 2016). One reason is likely that the highly diversified plant community increases the types and quality of litter, which in turn promotes the diversity of soil microorganisms. Higher microbial diversity can accelerate the decomposition of litter, accelerate accumulation and circulation of soil nutrients, and ultimately promote increasing soil multifunctionality (Delgado-Baquerizo et al., 2016;Reich et al., 2012). The indirect effect of plants on soil multifunctionality through soil microorganisms is also consistent with the early saturation of plant diversity and the time lag of soil multifunctionality during the restoration process (Fig. 2).

Previous studies show that the soil microbial community supports key ecological processes such as the decomposition of organic matter and nutrient cycling and is the basic mechanism for the connection between the above-and belowground communities in the terrestrial ecosystem (Van Der Heijden, Bardgett, & Van Straalen, 2008;Wardle et al., 2004). Our study supports these findings.

The restoration of above-ground plant communities by aerial seeding can restore degraded mobile dunes by promoting soil microorganisms and further improving soil multifunctionality. The high level plant diversity can enable microorganisms to enhance the drive of soil nutrient cycling (Delgado-Baquerizo et al., 2016;Reich et al., 2012) because the resource availability of soil microbial communities is limited by organic compounds in dead leaves and roots, especially underground biomass (Zak, Holmes, White, Peacock, & Tilman, 2003). Our findings are also consistent that underground biomass has a higher correlation with soil microbial diversity (Fig. S3D, H, L and S4D, H, L). Since different plant species have different biochemical compositions, highly diversified plant communities can provide more litter and more organic compounds, and the resource availability of microorganisms will be less restricted (Zak et al., 2003), thus changing the composition of soil microbial community to increase diversity (Hooper et al., 2000). Plant growth can also greatly change the soil microbial community through the release of root exudates (Badri & Vivanco, 2009;Shi et al., 2016). In addition, the improvement of soil microbial diversity can further accelerate the decomposition of litter from plants, increase the content of soil organic matter and accelerate the rate of nutrient cycling (Van Der Heijden et al., 2008;Wardle et al., 2004). Therefore, soil microorganisms play an important role in this positive circulation process, which increases the material circulation rate of the sandy land ecosystem being restored, and ultimately promotes soil multifunctionality (Delgado-Baquerizo et al., 2016).

div.head: Bacteria are the main factor that directly drives soil multifunctionality
div.p: Research on the role of soil microorganisms as drivers of soil multifunctionality have found that fungi or bacteria in different ecosystems have different effects on soil multifunctionality (Delgado-Baquerizo et al., 2016;Jiao et al., 2018). Our study with Random Forests analysis used multiple above-and belowground as predictors. The results show that the four significant factors in the sandy land ecosystem were all bacteria-related factors (Fig. 5), while no fungi-related factors were significant. First, soil bacteria account for 60-70% of the total soil microorganisms (Paul, 2014), and soil multifunctionality is significantly positively correlated with the diversity of fungi and bacteria (Fig. 3), but the larger total amount of bacteria may contribute more to the driving effect.

Second, it was traditionally believed that fungi are the key factor in litter decomposition, but recent studies have shown that in addition to fungi, bacteria also play an important role in litter decomposition (≈†tursov√°, ≈Ωifƒç√°kov√°, Leigh, Burgess, & Baldrian, 2012). The biomass of bacteria gradually increases during the decomposition process (Urbanov√° et al., 2014;Vo≈ô√≠≈°kov√° & Baldrian, 2013), as does the diversity of bacteria (Purahong et al., 2014;Tl√°skal, Vo≈ô√≠≈°kov√°, & Baldrian, 2016).

Moreover, bacteria contribute to a series of basic soil processes in the biogeochemical cycle, facilitating multiple key steps in the carbon and nitrogen cycle, such as nitrogen fixation (Llad√≥, L√≥pez-Mond√©jar, & Baldrian, 2017). These processes are also reflected in the CCA test between specific bacteria and the soil individual functions at the genus level (Fig. 6). For example, TN is highly correlated with Gp 10, and Gp 10 belongs to Agrobacterium, which can degrade plant residues and release nitrogen into the soil (Eichorst, Kuske, & Schmidt, 2011;Pankratov, Ivanova, Dedysh, & Liesack, 2011). TOC has a high correlation with Ilumatobacter, and Ilumatobacter belongs to Actinomycetes, which also plays an important role in the decomposition of cellulose in the soil (Vƒõtrovsk√Ω & Baldrian, 2015). Nitrospira and Bacillus, which are highly related to NO3 -, have the functions of soil nitrification and nitrogen fixation (Attard et al., 2010;Canbolat, Bilen, √áakmak√ßƒ±, ≈ûahin, & Aydƒ±n, 2006;Xia et al., 2011), Gp 17 is also highly related to NO3 -, which also belongs to Agrobacterium same as Gp 10, and can also release nitrogen to the soil by degrading plants.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: Based on the analysis of 32 field sites in the Mu Us Desert from 1983 to 2015, we showed that aerial

figure.figDesc: the climatic factor annual precipitation in our SEMs. Four SEMs were constructed for the four driving modes: plants alone, soil microorganisms alone, plants and soil microorganisms co-drive, and the indirect effects of plants on soil multifunctionality through soil microorganisms. In each SEM, the two variables of restoration time and annual precipitation were included. On this basis, the driving paths of plants and soil microorganisms on soil multifunctionality were constructed respectively to test their separate driving effects on soil multifunctionality. We then constructed the driving paths of plants and microorganisms to soil multifunctionality simultaneously to test the synergy effect of the two. Finally, the path from plants to microorganisms was added based on the synergy effect to test the indirect effects of restoration time, annual precipitation, and plants on soil multifunctionality. The two variables of plants and microorganisms are composed of multiple observation variables and cannot be measured directly, so two latent variables of "Plant" and "Microbe" were constructed. The latent variable Plant included four variables: Plant species richness, Plant shannon, Plant aboveground biomass, and Plant underground biomass. The latent variable Microbe included eight variables: Bacteria species richness, Bacteria shannon, Bacteria

seeding has promoted restoration of plant diversity, soil microbial diversity, and soil multifunctionality of mobile dunes. Plant diversity and soil microbial diversity respond quickly to restoration, with plant diversity approaching saturation already after 20 years, while soil multifunctionality responds to restoration with a clear time lag. On this restoration gradient, plants have a significant indirect driving on the restoration of soil multifunctionality through soil microorganisms, and the direct driving factor of soil multifunctionality is mainly soil bacteria. Soil microorganisms play a connecting role in the process of ecological restoration, which means that soil microorganisms is an important step in the true restoration mechanism. Our study clarifies the effectiveness of aerial seeding restoration measures in the Mu Us Desert and provides a new perspective for exploring the above-belowground driving factors of soil multifunctionality and their mode of driving. We hope that future measures and policies for restoration of degraded land and ecosystems can learn from the successful experience of aerial seeding measures and give equal attention to both plants and soil microorganisms in ecological restoration.
